Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: The evolution of anti-predator defenses in tortoise beetles (Coleoptera: Chrysomelidae: Cassidinae)
Award.AbstractNarration:
The evolutionary hypothesis of 'escape and radiation' posits that when a species develops a novel defense against its enemies (predators or parasites) this results in more rapid speciation, at least until the enemy species (or new enemy species) adapt to circumvent this defense. The evolution of yet another novel defensive trait resets the cycle anew, which ultimately results in the accumulation of species over evolutionary time. It has been suggested that this evolutionary processes is ubiquitous and can be found not only in plant-herbivore interactions but also in many other ecological associations, where it may likewise foster creation of new biodiversity over evolutionary time. Despite the theoretical importance of this hypothesis, evidence is limited that novel defense traits spurs the diversification of new species. This study will test this hypothesis using a species rich group of plant-eating beetles and an innovative set of field bioassay methods. The work will address whether novel defensive traits are narrow or broad in efficiency against predators, and whether the evolution of novel defense traits is correlated with increased rates of speciation. This project and the novel data it will produce, promise to transform systematic study of plant-insect interactions. Understanding defense trait evolution can reveal important and novel information about speciation patterns in insects, which can be important for agriculture, invasive species control, and sustaining biodiversity. This project will also support the research training of three undergraduates, and data, specimens, and images will be disseminated broadly via publicly accessible resources.

This project will provide an innovative study that will combine phylogenetics, chemical ecology, and bioassay performance experiments in an integrated approach that will enable the PIs to detect: (i) increased prey speciation rates due to the evolution of novel or more potent defensive traits; and (ii) whether the mechanism of diversification via novel defense acquisition is associated with broad-spectrum defenses, or with narrow, highly specific anti-predator adaptations. This study will significantly advance our understanding of the macroevolutionary processes that underlie the relationship between novel defensive trait evolution and prey diversification and will provide a suite of research tools for future investigations

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project sought to examine the nature, interactions, and sequence of behaviors involved in defenses of juvenile stages of Cassidinae (6000 species). These behaviors include living in groups, construction of fecal defenses in larvae, intricate morphology, chemistry, and maternal guarding of offspring. The project had three major goals: 1) Develop a well-resolved phylogeny of the tortoise beetle clade of Cassidinae; 2) Develop a library of defense chemicals in the host plants and in the larvae; and 3) Conduct field bioassays to quantify the effectiveness of defense behaviors.

Each goal was accomplished and more than 12 manuscripts are in preparation to report the results. Specimens and behavioral observations were assembled through fieldwork in Trinidad, Panama, and Peru and in collaborations with other researchers in Brazil, Ecuador, India, Mexico, and Australia. This pool of specimens provided material to refine DNA extraction protocols and to construct the genome-based phylogeny of Cassidinae (117 species). This phylogeny largely agrees with results of Chaboo (2007) and allowed analysis of the origin and sequence of each element in the defense arsenal in Cassidinae.

In parallel to the phylogeny study, behavioral experiments were conducted in Panama in 2017 and 2018 with two species, Chelymorpha alternans and Acromis sparsa, on the same host plant, Merremia umbellata (Convolvulaceae). These experiments examined how plant qualities might influence the vulnerability of larvae to predators (we used ants, spiders and praying mantises). The research team targeted two plant qualities, fungal endophytes and chemistry, and they found that these indeed influenced how easily beetle larvae were captured. Analyses of >450 host plants samples revealed the list of chemicals (modified metabolites and terpenoids) and we selected Caffeic acid, Thymol, Pheophorbide A, and Carvacrol to apply to beetle meal worms and so identify and isolate which chemicals were influencing the success of predators. It appears that these compounds did not change the chances of the larvae being caught.

In addition to the new specimen collections, chemical libraries, and manuscripts, the project created an international collaboration of researchers in several countries, discovered five species with subsociality (maternal guarding, and trained students (including minorities) in the USA, Trinidad, and Peru. Three American students spent long field periods in Panama, learning how to collect insect and plants and how to conduct behavioral experiments. Oral presentations of the research were made at two scientific meetings and a beetle exhibition was created and traveled to four sites, reaching school children, college students and the public.

Living openly on leaves is a harsh lifestyle and herbivorous insects are exposed to many enemies. The project is providing a better understanding of how vulnerable insects, particularly the young stages, can defend themselves from enemies. We now know that morphology, complex behaviors including maternal care, and chemistry can act together to reduce the chances of being eaten and enhance species survival over time. This research provides an excellent model to study and unravel how the largest groups of insects, the herbivores, achieved their dominance of life on Earth.
